questions.text: A 25-year-old woman has noted breast secretions for the past month. She is not breastfeeding and has never been pregnant. She has not menstruated for the past 5 months. Physical examination yields no abnormal findings. MRI of the brain shows a 0.7 cm mass within the sella turcica. Histopathological examination of the lesion after removal shows dystrophic calcification. Which of the following additional complications is she most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Prolactinomas are the most common hormone-secreting pituitary adenomas. Excess prolactin causes galactorrhea and amenorrhea by inhibiting GnRH and also leads to hypogonadism with decreased libido.
  • Microadenomas (< 1 cm) typically present via hormonal effects (galactorrhea, infertility, amenorrhea, and sexual dysfunction) without mass-effect signs like visual field defects.
  • Amenorrhea and infertility are secondary to prolactin-mediated suppression of GnRH and gonadotropins, distinguishing prolactinomas from GH-, ACTH-, or TSH-secreting tumours.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acromegaly (Option A): Caused by GH-secreting adenomas, leading to acral enlargement and coarse features, not galactorrhea or libido loss.

Cushing disease (Option B): From ACTH-secreting adenomas, presenting with cortisol excess (e.g., weight gain, hypertension), not prolactin effects.

Hyperthyroidism (Option C): Due to TSH-secreting adenomas, which are rare and produce thyrotoxic symptoms (tachycardia, weight loss), absent in this case.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with the acute onset of cessation of lactation. She delivered her first child several months ago and has been breastfeeding since then. She reports that she has not menstruated since the delivery. She also says that lately she has been tired and has been "feeling cold" all of the time. Laboratory workup reveals a deficiency of ACTH and other anterior pituitary hormones. What is the most likely cause of this patient's signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Sheehan's syndrome (postpartum pituitary necrosis) results from infarction of an enlarged anterior pituitary during obstetric haemorrhage or shock, leading to acute hypopituitarism.

Sheehan's Syndrome:

  • Hypopituitarism results from destructive processes that involve the adenohypophysis (anterior pituitary). These processes may be acute (sudden) or chronic.
  • Sheehan's syndrome, also known as postpartum pituitary necrosis, results from the sudden infarction of the anterior lobe of the pituitary. This can occur with obstetric complications, such as haemorrhage or shock.
  • The pituitary gland normally doubles in size during pregnancy; hypovolemia during delivery decreases blood flow and may result in infarction of the anterior pituitary. Sheehan's syndrome produces symptoms of hypopituitarism.
  • The initial sign is cessation of lactation, which may be followed by secondary amenorrhea due to the loss of gonadotropins.
  • Other signs of hypopituitarism include hypothyroidism and decreased functioning of the adrenal gland.
  • Acute destruction of the pituitary is also associated with DIC and thrombosis of the cavernous sinus.
  • Chronic causes of hypopituitarism include nonsecretory chromophobe pituitary adenomas, empty sella syndrome, and suprasellar (hypothalamic) tumours.
  • The term pituitary apoplexy refers to spontaneous haemorrhage into a pituitary tumour, while the empty sella syndrome is caused by a defective diaphragma sellae, which permits CSF from the third ventricle to enter the sella. It may also be secondary to infarction or necrosis. A CT scan reveals the sella to be enlarged or to appear empty.

Explanation of Other Options:

  • Craniopharyngioma (Option A): A suprasellar tumour of Rathke's pouch remnants causing gradual hypopituitarism and mass effects (headache, visual field defects), not acute postpartum infarction.
  • Cushing disease (Option B): Due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, causes cortisol excess (weight gain, hypertension), not loss of pituitary function.
  • Empty sella syndrome (Option C): Pituitary flattening from diaphragma sellae defect or prior infarction; often incidental or chronic, not acute postpartum failure.

questions.text: An 18-year-old has been experiencing headaches, polyuria, and visual problems for the past 5 months. On physical examination, he has bilateral temporal visual field deficits. CT scan of the head shows a large, partially calcified, cystic mass occupying the sellar and suprasellar areas. Removal of the lesion was done, and its histopathological image is shown below. What is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Tumour shows palisading epithelium, wet keratin and stellate reticulum, which is characteristic of adamantinomatous craniopharyngioma.

Craniopharyngiomas:

  • Craniopharyngiomas are uncommon, usually suprasellar neoplasms; they are typically found in young individuals.
  • They are thought to arise from embryological remnants of the Rathke pouch in the region of the pituitary.
  • These are aggressive neoplasms that infiltrate and destroy the surrounding tissues, making a complete excision difficult.
  • Despite their aggressive behaviour, they are composed of benign-appearing squamoid or primitive tooth structures.
  • The increase in prolactin occurs as a "stalk section" effect, and the hypernatremia results from diabetes insipidus caused by the destruction of the hypothalamus, posterior pituitary, or both. A metastasis to this location in a young individual is highly unlikely.

Explanation of Other Options:

Pituitary adenoma (Option B): Typically solid and non-calcified; histology lacks wet keratin and stellate reticulum.

Metastatic carcinoma (Option C): Rare in adolescents, usually multiple lesions, and shows malignant features distinct from benign-appearing craniopharyngioma squamous nests.

Germ cell tumour (Option D): May occur suprasellarly but displays primitive germ cells with markers like AFP or β-hCG, not wet keratin or palisading epithelium.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female complains of midline swelling of her neck, which she first noticed 4 months ago. Except for some discomfort during swallowing, the patient does not report any significant symptoms. Physical examination and ultrasound findings reveal a symmetrically enlarged thyroid. Laboratory findings revealed raised TSH 22.5 mIU/mL. An excised thyroid tissue is shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The given image is classic for Nontoxic goitre.

Nontoxic goitres range from double the size of a normal gland (40 g) to massive thyroid glands weighing hundreds of grams.

Microscopically, nontoxic goitre exhibits hypertrophy and hyperplasia. There is marked variation in the size of the follicles (see photomicrograph), fibrosis, and evidence of old haemorrhage.

Morphologic Types:

  • Diffuse colloid goitre: uniform enlargement without nodules.
  • Multinodular goitre: asymmetric, nodular gland from long-standing hyperplasia/involution.

The diffuse form is frequent in adolescence and during pregnancy, whereas the multinodular type usually occurs in persons older than 50 years of age.

Imaging & Biopsy:

  • Ultrasound: heterogeneous echotexture, multiple colloid-filled nodules.
  • Radioiodine scan: variable uptake ("hot" and "cold" nodules).

Management:

  • Iodine supplementation (in deficiency areas).
  • Thyroid hormone replacement to suppress TSH and reduce goitre size.
  • Surgical thyroidectomy for large, symptomatic, or suspicious nodules.
  • Radioiodine therapy in selected cases of toxic nodular goitre.

Explanation of Other Options:

Follicular adenoma (Option A): A benign, encapsulated neoplasm with uniform "back-to-back" follicles and no intervening fibrosis or haemorrhage.

Graves' disease (Option B): A toxic diffuse goitre with suppressed TSH, papillary infoldings, and a hypervascular ("thyroid inferno") appearance.

Hashimoto's thyroiditis (Option C): Characterised by dense lymphocytic infiltrates with germinal centres and Hurthle cell change, absent here.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female complains of chronic constipation and anovulatory cycles for the last 6 months. Her vital signs are normal. Physical examination reveals peripheral oedema. USG neck examination shows a diffusely enlarged thyroid gland. Laboratory investigations show abnormally low serum levels of T3 and T4. The patient underwent thyroidectomy. The excised histopathological image of the specimen is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is the appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

There is extensive infiltration of the parenchyma by a mononuclear inflammatory infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres. The thyroid follicles are atrophic and are lined in many areas by epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm, termed Hurthle cells, which represent a metaplastic response of the normally low cuboidal follicular epithelium to chronic injury. All of these features are suggestive of autoimmune (Hashimoto's) thyroiditis.

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient regions and is mediated by anti-thyroid peroxidase and anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, leading to gradual thyroid destruction.

Clinically, patients present with a painless goitre and symptoms of hypothyroidism (fatigue, cold intolerance, and menstrual irregularities). There is also a small increased risk of progression to primary thyroid B-cell lymphoma.

Explanation of Other Options:

Colloid goitre (Option A): Demonstrates variable follicles engorged with colloid but lacks a significant inflammatory infiltrate.

Granulomatous thyroiditis (Option B): Subacute (De Quervain) thyroiditis shows granulomas with multinucleated giant cells, not lymphoid germinal centres or Hürthle cells.

Low-grade B-cell lymphoma (Option D): Shows a monotonous infiltrate of atypical lymphocytes effacing thyroid architecture without Hurthle cell change.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with neck swelling. USG neck performed shows a nodule in the left lobe of the thyroid. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration cytology reveals malignant cells. The tumour is excised and examined by light microscopy (shown in the image). What is the appropriate pathological diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Papillary carcinoma displays branching papillae with a central fibrovascular core, lined by epithelial cells exhibiting clear ("Orphan Annie eye") nuclei, nuclear grooves, and intranuclear pseudoinclusions.
  • It is the most common thyroid malignancy in young adults, often multifocal, with a strong tendency for lymphatic spread to regional nodes.
  • Patients typically have an excellent prognosis, with >95% 10-year survival after surgical excision and appropriate radioactive iodine ablation.

Comparative Features of Common Thyroid Carcinomas

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented for routine examination. He was advised for a routine test, and a single cervical lymph node enlargement was detected on ultrasound. A solitary nodule was also identified in the thyroid. Histhyroid function tests are normal and FNAC from cervical lymph nodes shows reactive lymphoid hyperplasia. Scintigraphy shows cold masses (suspected malignancy). Thyroidectomy was done, and the histopathological image is shown below. All these features can be seen in this lesion, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Papillary thyroid carcinoma is defined by its distinctive nuclear features - optically clear "Orphan Annie-eye" nuclei, intranuclear pseudoinclusions, and nuclear grooves as well as psammoma bodies. Hurthle cells (oncocytic change) are not part of this tumour's morphology.

The presence of Hurthle cells, which are enlarged follicular cells with abundant granular, eosinophilic cytoplasm, suggests a different pathology (e.g., Hurthle cell neoplasm or chronic thyroiditis), not papillary carcinoma.

Recognising the absence of oncocytic cytoplasm helps distinguish papillary carcinoma from follicular/oncocytic variants and avoids diagnostic confusion.

Hurthle cell neoplasm

Comparative Features of Common Thyroid Carcinomas

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with swelling in the anterior part of his neck. Physical examination reveals an enlarged nodular thyroid. Thyroid function tests are within normal limits. A thyroid scintiscan shows a dominant "hot" nodule. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Follicular carcinoma is diagnosed by capsular and/or vascular invasion of neoplastic follicles, as shown by the arrow penetrating the capsule, distinguishing it from benign follicular adenoma.

Some well-differentiated follicular carcinomas retain enough iodine-concentrating ability to appear "hot" on radionuclide scans, unlike most thyroid cancers.

Patients with follicular carcinoma often present euthyroid, and definitive diagnosis requires histologic evidence of invasion despite benign-appearing follicular architecture.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anaplastic carcinoma (Option A): Presents in elderly patients with rapidly enlarging, fixed masses and pleomorphic giant or spindle cells; never "hot" on scan.

Medullary carcinoma (Option C): Derived from parafollicular C-cells; nests of polygonal or spindle cells with amyloid stroma, no follicular architecture or hot uptake.

Follicular adenoma (Option D): Benign, encapsulated follicular growth without capsular/vascular invasion; may appear as a hot nodule but lacks invasive features.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman has noted increasing fullness in her neck for the past 3 months. On physical examination, her thyroid gland is diffusely and asymmetrically enlarged. There is no lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound of the neck showed the presence of malignant nodules. She undergoes thyroidectomy. Gross examination of the thyroid shows nodules, and the histopathological image is shown below. Based on the above findings, what is your probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • Medullary carcinoma originates from parafollicular C cells and is characterised by nests or trabeculae of polygonal to spindle cells embedded in an amyloid-rich stroma derived from calcitonin, explaining the amorphous deposits seen histologically.
  • This tumour often presents as a nodular enlargement in a euthyroid patient and may be part of MEN 2 syndromes; serum calcitonin levels aid in diagnosis and postoperative monitoring.
  • Unlike follicular or papillary thyroid cancers, medullary carcinoma does not concentrate radioiodine and requires total thyroidectomy with central neck lymph node dissection due to its propensity for early lymphatic spread.

Explanation of Other Options:

Papillary carcinoma of thyroid (Option A): Shows branching papillae with "Orphan Annie-eye" nuclei and psammoma bodies, not amyloid stroma.

Follicular carcinoma (Option B): Composed of uniform follicles with capsular and vascular invasion, lacking C-cell nests and extracellular amyloid.

Anaplastic carcinoma (Option D): Consists of highly pleomorphic giant and spindle cells without organised nests or amyloid; occurs in older patients with rapid growth.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with swelling in her neck that she first noticed 4 months ago. She also complains of intermittent watery diarrhoea over the same time period. Physical examination reveals a nontender and nodular lesion in the left lobe of the thyroid. The patient's mother died of thyroid cancer 8 years ago. The thyroid nodule is found to be "cold" by radioiodine scintiscan. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy due to the possibility of tumorigenesis. The histopathological image of the patient is shown below. Laboratory studies would likely show elevated blood levels of which of the following hormones in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells that secrete calcitonin. Amyloid in the stroma represents calcitonin-derived deposits.

Calcitonin is the principal hormone produced by C cells, and its serum elevation is both sensitive and specific for medullary carcinoma.

C cells do not uptake iodine, explaining the "cold" appearance on scintigraphy despite tumour presence.

Explanation of Other Options:

Procalcitonin (Option B): A prohormone elevated in systemic inflammation and sepsis, not produced by thyroid C cells.

Parathyroid hormone (Option C): Secreted by parathyroid glands to raise serum calcium; unrelated to thyroid C-cell tumours.

Thyroid-stimulating hormone (Option D): Pituitary-derived regulator of follicular cells; levels would be normal or suppressed, not elevated in medullary carcinoma.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman has had angina pectoris, polyuria, and polydipsia for the past 3 years. On physical examination, she has a body mass index of 32. Laboratory studies show her HbA1c value of 14.4. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, but no ketonuria. The representative microscopic appearance of her kidneys is shown in the figure. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism leading to the disease causing her findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Insulin resistance in peripheral tissues is the hallmark of type 2 diabetes mellitus, leading to chronic hyperglycemia, nonenzymatic glycation of proteins, and mesangial expansion with nodular glomerulosclerosis.

Obesity (BMI 32), severe hyperglycemia without ketonuria, and long-standing disease with macrovascular (angina) and microvascular (proteinuria) complications fit the natural history of insulin-resistant diabetes.

Hyperinsulinemia and endothelial dysfunction promote glomerular hyperfiltration and basement membrane thickening, progressing to proteinuria and Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules characteristic of diabetic nephropathy.

Explanation of Other Options:

Chronic pancreatitis (Option A): Primarily affects the exocrine pancreas with pain and malabsorption; diabetes can occur late but is not characteristically insulin resistant or associated with nodular glomerulosclerosis.

Glucokinase gene mutation (Option B): Causes a mild, stable fasting hyperglycemia (MODY 2) with low risk of microvascular complications; does not lead to aggressive nephropathy.

Type 1 diabetes mellitus (Option D): Results from autoimmune β-cell destruction with insulin deficiency and ketoacidosis; typically presents earlier, with ketonuria, and develops nephropathy over a longer duration.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man has had a nonhealing ulcer on the bottom of his foot for 3 months. On examination, the 2 cm ulcer overlies the right first metatarsal head. There is reduced sensation to pinprick in his feet. His visual acuity is reduced bilaterally. Laboratory studies show serum creatinine is 2 mg/dL. Which of the following laboratory test findings is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The combination of peripheral neuropathy, retinopathy, nephropathy (elevated creatinine), and a chronic foot ulcer is classic for long-standing diabetes mellitus.
  • Persistent hyperglycemia exceeds the renal tubular threshold for glucose reabsorption, resulting in glucosuria.
  • Other options (hypoalbuminemia, hypokalemia, leukopenia) are not primary manifestations of diabetic microvascular disease.

Explanation of Other Options:

Hypoalbuminemia (Option B): Occurs in advanced nephrotic syndrome from any etiology, not specifically early diabetic nephropathy.

Hypokalemia (Option C): Results from states of aldosterone excess or diuretic use, not from diabetes mellitus per se.

Leukopenia (Option D): Arises from bone marrow disorders or infections, not a feature of diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman has had several "fainting spells" over the past 6 months. Each time, she has a prodrome of lightheadedness followed by a brief loss of consciousness. After each episode, she awakens and, on examination, has no loss of motor or sensory function. Physical examination after the current episode shows that she is afebrile, with a pulse of 72/min, respirations of 17/min, and blood pressure of 120/80 mm Hg. Imaging studies reveal a 0.5 cm lesion in the head of the pancreas. The microscopic appearance of this lesion is shown in the figure. Which of the following pancreatic disorders is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The figure shows a circumscribed cellular lesion in the pancreas, most suggestive of a pancreatic neuroendocrine tumour (PanNET).

  • Secretion of insulin by these lesions causes hypoglycemia and the described symptoms. Many of these tumours are less than 1 cm in diameter, making them difficult to detect.
  • Most patients who have an insulin-secreting PanNET have only mild insulin hypersecretion.
  • The laboratory finding of an increased insulin-to-glucose ratio is helpful.
  • Surgical excision is necessary in patients with marked symptoms.

Explanation of Other Options:

Acute necrotising pancreatitis (Option A): Causes widespread acinar cell injury, fat necrosis, and systemic inflammation, no discrete tumour or insulin hypersecretion.

Adenocarcinoma (Option B): A ductal epithelial malignancy with gland-forming cells and desmoplastic stroma, does not secrete insulin.

Carcinoid tumour (Option C): A serotonin-secreting neuroendocrine neoplasm causing flushing and diarrhoea (carcinoid syndrome). Histology shows trabeculae and rosettes but not insulin-mediated hypoglycemia.

choices.text: Cells typically show a zellballen pattern of arrangement
Cells vary from polygonal to spindle-shaped cells
Cytoplasm of the cells is fine-granular and contains granules of catecholamine
The nuclei show pleomorphism with prominent nucleoli

questions.text: A 54-year-old male patient presented with a history of hypertension for a long time. These days he is having high blood pressure along with palpitations, headache, sweating and occasional tremor. In spite of medication, symptoms persist. He underwent a whole-body CT scan, and a well-circumscribed lesion was identified in the adrenal medulla, for which he underwent surgery. Histopathological examination (image shown below) of the lesion will show all of the findings, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The given image and the symptoms suggest a Pheochromocytoma. Nuclei in pheochromocytoma are usually uniform, round to ovoid with stippled "salt-and-pepper" chromatin and lack significant pleomorphism or conspicuous nucleoli.

Pheochromocytoma

  • Tumour of adrenal medullary chromaffin (C) cells producing excess catecholamines
  • Clinical Presentation
    • Paroxysmal or sustained hypertension.
    • Classic triad: episodic headache, sweating, tachycardia/palpitations.
    • Other features: pallor, anxiety, tremor, hyperglycemia.
  • The histologic pattern in pheochromocytoma is quite variable. The tumours are composed of clusters of polygonal to spindle-shaped chromaffin cells or chief cells that are surrounded by supporting sustentacular cells, creating small nests or alveoli (zellballen) that are supplied by a rich vascular network. (Option A)
  • Uncommonly, the dominant cell type is a spindle or small cell; various patterns can be found in any one tumour. (Option B)
  • The cytoplasm has a finely granular appearance, best demonstrated with silver stains, due to the presence of granules containing catecholamines. (Option C)
  • Nuclei in pheochromocytoma are usually uniform, round to ovoid with stippled "salt-and-pepper" chromatin and lack significant pleomorphism or conspicuous nucleoli.
  • Electron microscopy reveals variable numbers of membrane-bound, electron-dense secretory granules.

Zellballen pattern

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a long-standing history of type 2 diabetes mellitus suffers a massive hemorrhagic stroke and expires. Examination of the pancreas shows hyalinization of many islets of Langerhans. Which of the following characterises the material within the islets of Langerhans?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • In type 2 diabetes mellitus, islet hyalinization reflects deposition of amyloid derived from islet amyloid polypeptide (IAPP, or amylin), a β-cell peptide co-secreted with insulin.
  • In T2DM, amyloid is often present within the islets, particularly in patients over 60 years of age. This IAPP-derived amyloid forms β-pleated fibrils that stain with Congo red and exhibit apple-green birefringence under polarised light.
  • Up to 20% of aged nondiabetic individuals also have islet amyloid deposits, attributed to age-related IAPP aggregation rather than overt diabetes.
  • None of the other choices - Amyloid AB2 (β2-microglobulin), fibrin, or proteoglycan - demonstrates Congo red positivity with apple-green birefringence in pancreatic islets.

Congo red staining of amyloid

Apple green birefringence

Explanation of Other Options:

Amyloid AB2 (Option B): β2-Microglobulin amyloid occurs in dialysis-related amyloidosis, depositing in joints and soft tissues, not in pancreatic islets.

Fibrin (Option C): A clotting protein forming thrombi; does not create extracellular islet deposits.

Proteoglycan (Option D): Connective tissue matrix component; not involved in islet hyalinization.

questions.text: A patient presented with neck swelling. Cytology showed parafollicular cells along with clusters of plasmacytoid and scant amyloid. What investigation should be done to follow up with the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Parafollicular cells, along with clusters of plasmacytoid and scant amyloid, are suggestive of medullary carcinoma thyroid gland. Serum calcitonin levels are used as a tumour marker in this case.

Medullary carcinoma arises from C cells that secrete calcitonin; elevated calcitonin correlates with tumour burden and is both diagnostic and prognostic.

Calcitonin doubling time predicts aggressiveness. Rapid doubling indicates a higher risk of recurrence or metastasis.

Measurement of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) may complement calcitonin levels, and genetic testing for RET mutations is recommended, given associations with MEN 2 syndromes.

Explanation of Other Options:

TSH level (Option B): Reflects pituitary-thyroid axis and is not useful for C-cell-derived tumours.

Anti-TPO antibody (Option C): Indicates autoimmune thyroiditis and is irrelevant to medullary carcinoma.

TRH stimulation test (Option D): Assesses TSH reserve and has no role in monitoring calcitonin-producing tumours.

Key Takeaways:

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is best monitored with serum calcitonin (and CEA) rather than standard thyroid function tests or autoantibodies.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented with a thyroid swelling and dysphagia. He gave a history of on-and-off watery diarrhoea. Biopsy of the lesion is shown. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Medullary carcinoma arises from parafollicular C cells, which secrete calcitonin; misfolded calcitonin aggregates form the characteristic amyloid stroma visible on biopsy.

Paraneoplastic diarrhoea:

  • Many medullary carcinomas co-secrete vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) or other peptides (e.g., prostaglandins), producing a secretory diarrhoea syndrome that explains this patient's watery stools.

Tumour markers and genetics:

  • Serum calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) levels rise proportionally to tumour burden; up to 25% of MTCs are hereditary (MEN 2A/2B) with RET proto-oncogene mutations.

Explanation of Other Options:

Follicular carcinoma (Option A): Shows uniform follicles with capsular/vascular invasion; no amyloid or peptide-induced diarrhoea.

Papillary carcinoma (Option B): Characterised by papillary fronds, Orphan Annie-eye nuclei, and psammoma bodies; not associated with amyloid or VIP secretion.

Anaplastic carcinoma (Option D): Undifferentiated giant and spindle cells with rapid local invasion; lacks organised nests, amyloid, or hormonal syndromes.

questions.text: Biopsy from the resected mass has been shown. What is the finding and diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The tumour demonstrates classic "Zellballen" architecture - nests of polygonal chromaffin cells with abundant granular cytoplasm surrounded by sustentacular cells - pathognomonic for
  • These lesions arise in the adrenal medulla, secrete excess catecholamines, and present clinically with paroxysmal hypertension, headaches, sweating, and palpitations.
  • Histochemical stains (chromogranin A, synaptophysin) confirm neuroendocrine differentiation, and S100 highlights the sustentacular cell network around Zellballen nests.

Explanation of Other Options:

Zellballen in RCC (Option A): RCC shows clear cells with a rich vascular stroma, not nested Zellballen of chromaffin cells.

Follicular carcinoma in renal metastasis (Option C): Metastatic follicular thyroid carcinoma retains follicular architecture with colloid, not Zellballen nests.

Homer Wright rosettes in neuroblastoma (Option D): Neuroblastoma exhibits small blue cells forming rosettes around neuropil, not the adrenal chromaffin Zellballen pattern.

choices.text: Kimmelstein-Wilson lesion, diabetic non-proliferative retinopathy due to macroangiopathy
Diffuse glomerulosclerosis, diabetic proliferative retinopathy due to macroangiopathy
Kimmelstein-Wilson lesion, diabetic non-proliferative retinopathy due to microangiopathy
Diffuse glomerulosclerosis, diabetic proliferative retinopathy due to microangiopathy

questions.text: Kidney biopsy findings and ophthalmoscopy findings from a patient with Type II diabetes of 25 years have been shown below. Identify the findings and pathology.
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The kidney biopsy shows spherical, laminated nodules of mesangial matrix at the periphery of glomeruli, which are PAS-positive and termed nodular (Kimmelstiel-Wilson) glomerulosclerosis, pathognomonic of long-standing diabetic nephropathy.
  • The retinal findings - microaneurysms and dot-blot haemorrhages without new vessel formation define non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy, a microangiopathic complication of chronic hyperglycemia rather than macrovascular disease.
  • Chronic hyperglycemia induces nonenzymatic glycation of basement membrane proteins, polyol pathway flux, oxidative stress, and PKC activation, leading to basement membrane thickening, pericyte loss, and capillary dropout in both glomeruli and retinal vessels.
  • Clinically, diabetic nephropathy progresses from microalbuminuria to overt proteinuria, hypertension, and eventual renal failure. Diabetic retinopathy advances from background changes to proliferative retinopathy with neovascularisation if glycemic control is poor.

Explanation of Other Options:

Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesion, diabetic non-proliferative retinopathy due to macroangiopathy (Option A): Incorrect, as retinopathy in diabetes is a microangiopathy; macroangiopathy refers to large-vessel atherosclerosis.

Diffuse glomerulosclerosis, diabetic proliferative retinopathy due to macroangiopathy (Option B): Incorrect, as diffuse mesangial expansion lacks nodular lesions, and proliferative retinopathy involves neovascularisation absent here.

Diffuse glomerulosclerosis, diabetic proliferative retinopathy due to microangiopathy (Option D): Incorrect, as diffuse glomerulosclerosis does not produce PAS-positive nodules, and proliferative retinopathy shows new vessel growth.

choices.text: Water clear cells in parathyroid Ca

questions.text: A biopsy from the parathyroid gland of a 55-year-old male who presented to the nephrology department of AIIMS is shown below. He is a known case of chronic kidney disease with hypertension and type II diabetes. He has recently developed bone pain, lesions in the skin and recurrent stones in the kidney
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The given histology shows abundant optically clear cells (water-clear cells) with variable size, spherical clear vacuoles, and thin eosinophilic rims, arranged in compact nests or alveolar patterns, characteristic of water-clear cell hyperplasia.

Pathogenesis in CKD:

  • In chronic kidney disease, phosphate retention and decreased 1,25-(OH)2 vitamin D lead to hypocalcemia, stimulating diffuse parathyroid chief cell hyperplasia (secondary hyperparathyroidism); the water-clear cell variant reflects cytoplasmic accumulation of glycogen or lipid.

Distinguishing hyperplasia from carcinoma:

  • Water-clear cell hyperplasia is multicentric and lacks a capsule, invasive growth, significant atypia, or mitotic figures, distinguishing it from water-clear cell carcinoma.

Clinical correlation:

  • Excess PTH drives bone resorption (bone pain, subperiosteal resorption), soft tissue and vascular calcifications (skin lesions), and hypercalciuria with nephrolithiasis (kidney stones).

Explanation of Other Options:

Water-clear cells in parathyroid carcinoma (Option B): Carcinoma would present as a solitary, encapsulated mass with capsular/vascular invasion, fibrosis, and cytologic atypia - none of which are seen here.

Tuberculous granulomas of parathyroid (Option C): Would show caseating granulomas, epithelioid macrophages, and Langhans giant cells, not clear cell vacuolation.

Parathyroid necrosis (Option D): Characterised by haemorrhage, necrotic debris, and loss of cellular detail rather than organised nests of clear cells.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female of Asian Indian origin was admitted to the orthopaedic emergency department with pain in her left shoulder region, right knee, and left thigh following a trivial trauma. On physical examination of the patient, tenderness was found to be present in the left shoulder, right knee, and left thigh. On laboratory analysis, serum calcium level was 11.4 mg/dL (normal 8.4-10.7 mg/dL), serum alkaline phosphatase level was 780 IU/L (normal 50-240 IU/L), serum parathyroid hormone level was 456 pg/mL (normal 7-53 pg/mL), vitamin D3 (1,25-dihydroxy cholecalciferol) was 32 pg/mL (normal 25-45 pg/mL). A biopsy done from the lesion is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The histology demonstrates a fibrovascular stroma populated by numerous osteoclast-type multinucleated giant cells, areas of haemorrhage, and abundant hemosiderin-laden macrophages, imparting a brown colouration - hallmarks of a brown tumour (osteitis fibrosa cystica).

Brown tumours are reparative granulomatous lesions arising from excessive osteoclastic bone resorption driven by markedly elevated PTH in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Clinically, primary hyperparathyroidism presents with "bones, stones, abdominal groans, and psychic moans": bone pain, subperiosteal bone resorption, pathological fractures, nephrolithiasis, and neuropsychiatric symptoms.

Laboratory findings: Hypercalcemia, elevated PTH, and high ALP correlate with osteoclastic activity and bone turnover.

Radiographically, brown tumours appear as well-defined lytic lesions. Surgical or medical correction of hyperparathyroidism leads to lesion regression.

questions.text: Reticular fibres are not seen as the structural framework of:
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

The fully developed thymus comprises two fused, encapsulated lobes divided by fibrous septa into cortical and medullary lobules.

Unlike other lymphoid organs, its parenchymal framework is formed by thymic epithelial cells (polygonal in the cortex with dendritic extensions, spindle-shaped in the medulla forming Hassall corpuscles), not by reticular (type III collagen) fibres.

Reticular fibres are limited to the capsule and septa; they do not permeate the thymic cortex or medulla as a supporting meshwork.

In contrast, reticular fibres are abundant throughout the splenic white and red pulp, bone marrow hematopoietic cords, and lymph node cortical and medullary cords, providing scaffolding for lymphocytes and hematopoietic cells.

questions.text: GNAS mutation is associated with malignancy in which cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • The GNAS gene encodes the Gsα subunit of the stimulatory G protein; activating (gain-of-function) mutations cause constitutive adenylate cyclase activation and elevated cAMP levels.
  • These mutations drive proliferation and hormone overproduction specifically in somatotrophs (growth-hormone–secreting cells), leading to sporadic GH-secreting pituitary adenomas and the endocrine features of McCune-Albright syndrome.
  • Approximately 30 - 40% of sporadic growth-hormone secreting pituitary tumours harbour activating GNAS mutations, underscoring their role in somatotroph neoplasia.

Explanation of Other Options:

Lactotroph (Option A): Prolactinomas lack GNAS mutations and are driven by other molecular alterations.

Thyrotroph (Option C): TSH-secreting tumours do not commonly show GNAS activation.

Corticotroph (Option D): ACTH-secreting (Cushing disease) adenomas are not associated with GNAS mutations.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with neck swelling. Gross and histology are shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Sporadic medullary thyroid carcinomas present as a solitary nodule. In contrast, bilaterality and multicentricity are common in familial cases.

Larger lesions often contain areas of necrosis and haemorrhage and may extend through the capsule of the thyroid. The tumour tissue is firm, pale grey to tan, and infiltrative.

Microscopically, medullary carcinomas are composed of polygonal to spindle-shaped cells, which may form nests, trabeculae, and even follicles. Small, more anaplastic cells are present in some tumours and may be the predominant cell type.

Acellular amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma in many cases

Explanation of Other Options:

Hashimoto's thyroiditis (Option B): Features dense lymphocytic infiltrates with germinal centres and Hürthle cell change, not tumour nests or amyloid.

Anaplastic carcinoma (Option C): Occurs in elderly patients as undifferentiated pleomorphic giant and spindle cells with aggressive invasion, lacking organised C-cell nests or amyloid.

Follicular carcinoma (Option D): Composed of uniform follicles with capsular and vascular invasion, without amyloid deposits or C-cell features.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a solitary 2 cm thyroid nodule. She is euthyroid and has no cervical lymphadenopathy. Ultrasound shows a solid lesion, and fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is performed. While FNAC can accurately identify many thyroid malignancies, it cannot definitively diagnose which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

Follicular carcinoma is defined by capsular and/or vascular invasion - features that depend on seeing the tumour capsule and adjacent blood vessels in a surgical specimen.

Limitations of FNAC:

  • Cytology provides cells and small clusters but no information about their relationship to the capsule or vasculature, so FNAC cannot distinguish follicular carcinoma (invasive) from follicular adenoma (noninvasive).

Cytologic overlap:

  • Both follicular adenomas and carcinomas yield similar follicular cell morphology on FNAC (microfollicular or trabecular patterns), making malignancy impossible to confirm without histology.

Explanation of Other Options:

Anaplastic carcinoma (Option B): FNAC shows markedly pleomorphic, spindle, and giant cells - distinctive features allowing cytologic diagnosis.

Papillary carcinoma (Option C): Characteristic nuclear features (Orphan Annie-eye nuclei, grooves, pseudoinclusions) are readily identified on cytology.

Medullary carcinoma (Option D): Plasmacytoid C cells and amyloid fragments on FNAC, confirmed by calcitonin immunostaining, make FNAC highly sensitive

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis of a patient who has prolactinoma, parathyroid hyperplasia and a family history of renal stones?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • MEN-I (Wermer syndrome) arises from germline MEN1 mutations (menin loss) and is defined by the "3 Ps":
    • Pituitary adenomas (most often prolactinomas or GH-secreting tumours)
    • Parathyroid hyperplasia (primary hyperparathyroidism → hypercalcemia, nephrolithiasis)
    • Pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours (gastrinomas, insulinomas, VIPomas, others)

Components of MEN Syndromes

Explanation of Other Options:

  • MEN-II (Option B): Combines medullary thyroid carcinoma and pheochromocytoma (± parathyroid hyperplasia) but does not include pituitary adenomas.
  • NF1 (Option C): Features cafe-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, Lisch nodules; not a pituitary-parathyroid-pancreas syndrome.
  • Li-Fraumeni syndrome (Option D): Involves germline TP53 mutations with sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumours, and adrenocortical carcinoma; not the MEN pattern.
